questions.text: Using extra writing space shows thoroughness and earns more marks.
questions.explanation: The lines provided indicate expected response length. Extending into extra space isn't obligatory and often means you're overwriting. Stay concise and focused.
questions.studyTip: Lines provided = length expected. Extra space is optional, not bonus.

questions.text: When using extra space, clearly indicate this in the original answer area and label responses in the extra space.
questions.explanation: If you do use extra space, mark it clearly: 'Continued in extra space' and label your continuation with the question number. Assessors need to follow your response.
questions.studyTip: Extra space? Label both ends: 'See extra space' and 'Q1c continued'.

questions.text: Spending extra time on Section A ensures strong source analysis marks.
questions.explanation: Some students complete more than two Section A questions but then fail to attempt or fully construct a Section B essay. Balance your time—both sections matter.
questions.studyTip: Section A: 50 marks. Section B: 20 marks. Budget time accordingly.

questions.text: Attempting more than two Section A questions often results in a weaker essay response.
questions.explanation: Students who overdo Section A frequently produce less well-constructed essays. Stick to the required number of questions and give Section B adequate time.
questions.studyTip: Two Section A questions. One essay. No extras.

questions.text: It's obvious which revolution you're discussing from your content, so labelling isn't essential.
questions.explanation: Always explicitly specify which revolution you're addressing. Clear labelling helps assessors and avoids any confusion about which option you've chosen.
questions.studyTip: Write the revolution name at the start. Remove all doubt.

questions.text: Explicitly naming your revolution at the start of each response is expected and helps assessors.
questions.explanation: Students who clearly specify their revolution demonstrate familiarity with exam requirements. This is a basic but important skill.
questions.studyTip: First line: 'The French Revolution' or similar. Always.

questions.text: Dot points are appropriate for all question types in Section A.
questions.explanation: Dot points work for 2-mark 'identify' questions. For 'describe' questions (4 marks), signposted sentences connecting features to source elements are more appropriate.
questions.studyTip: Identify = dot points OK. Describe = sentences with signposting.

questions.text: Using 'firstly', 'secondly', 'thirdly' or similar signposting helps structure longer responses.
questions.explanation: Signposting creates clear structure and shows you're addressing multiple points systematically. It helps both your thinking and the assessor's reading.
questions.studyTip: Signpost to show structure: Firstly... Secondly... Finally...

concepts.title: Use quotation marks for source material

questions.text: Paraphrasing source material in your own words shows understanding.
questions.explanation: For entry-level questions, paraphrasing sometimes leads to errors. Explicitly transcribe source material using quotation marks to indicate when a source has been used.
questions.studyTip: Quote directly with quotation marks. Paraphrasing risks errors.

questions.text: Quotation marks should explicitly indicate when written source material has been used.
questions.explanation: Direct quotes with quotation marks show you're accurately using the source. Add source references: 'Source 2', 'S2', or 'As seen in Source 2...'
questions.studyTip: Quote + 'Source X' = clear, credited source use.

concepts.title: Don't add own knowledge to identify/describe questions

questions.text: Adding your own knowledge to 'identify' questions shows deeper understanding.
questions.explanation: Entry-level questions (identify, describe) don't require own knowledge—use only the source material. Substituting source references with own knowledge is to be avoided.
questions.studyTip: Identify/describe = source only. Own knowledge not required or rewarded.

questions.text: For 'identify' and 'describe' questions, responses should be drawn entirely from the source material.
questions.explanation: These questions test your ability to read and use sources accurately. Own knowledge comes in later questions. Stick to what the source provides.
questions.studyTip: Source question = source answer. Save own knowledge for later.

questions.text: Copying the source at length shows you've read it carefully.
questions.explanation: Simply rewriting sources doesn't show understanding of the question's demands. For 'describe' questions, connect source features to clear elements and arguments—don't just transcribe.
questions.studyTip: Transcribing ≠ answering. Show you understand, don't just copy.

questions.text: For 'describe' questions, you must connect source features to arguments, not just copy the source.
questions.explanation: Describe questions require you to identify features AND connect them to the source's meaning or context. Raw transcription without analysis doesn't score well.
questions.studyTip: Describe = identify + connect to meaning. Not just quote.

questions.text: Only the visual elements of an image source should be used in responses.
questions.explanation: The text surrounding visual sources provides valuable information. Captions, titles, and dates can all be used to respond to part a. and b. questions.
questions.studyTip: Read EVERYTHING on the source: image, caption, date, title.

questions.text: Captions and text accompanying visual sources provide usable information for your response.
questions.explanation: Don't ignore the written context around images. This information is deliberately included and can help you answer questions about both visual and written features.
questions.studyTip: Caption says who, what, when? Use it!

questions.text: If your quote is clearly from the source, you don't need to name the source.
questions.explanation: Explicit source references are expected: 'S11', 'Source 11', 'as seen in Source 11'. Make it clear which source you're drawing from.
questions.studyTip: Always name the source: 'Source 2 states...' or '(S2)'.

questions.text: High-scoring responses explicitly reference sources using labels like 'Source 2' or 'S2'.
questions.explanation: Clear source attribution shows academic rigour. Whether you use full labels or abbreviations, make the source unmistakable.
questions.studyTip: Every quote needs a source label. No exceptions.

questions.text: 'Identify' questions require detailed explanation of the features you find.
questions.explanation: 'Identify' simply means extract and name features. There's no need to describe or expound. Dot points listing concrete features are sufficient for 2-mark questions.
questions.studyTip: Identify = list and name. Don't over-explain.

questions.text: For 'identify' questions, simply naming the relevant features is sufficient.
questions.explanation: Identify means locate and name. You don't need to explain why or how—just clearly state what you've found in the source. Keep it brief and accurate.
questions.studyTip: Two features asked = two features named. Done.

questions.text: 'Describe' questions can be answered the same way as 'identify' questions.
questions.explanation: 'Describe' requires more than identification. You must describe features AND connect them to clear elements of the source. Signposted sentences work better than dot points.
questions.studyTip: Describe = identify + explain what it shows.

questions.text: 'Describe' questions require signposted arguments connecting features to the source.
questions.explanation: Don't just list—describe how the features relate to the source's purpose, context, or meaning. Show understanding, not just observation.
questions.studyTip: This feature shows... This suggests... This indicates...

concepts.title: Explain: Why and how with own knowledge

questions.text: 'Explain' questions can be answered using only source material.
questions.explanation: 'Explain' questions explicitly require own knowledge combined with source material. Responses that only transpose source material don't score well.
questions.studyTip: Explain = sources + own knowledge. Both required.

questions.text: 'Explain' requires constructing an account of why/how, using both sources and own knowledge.
questions.explanation: Weave together the source material with your own contextual knowledge. Show causes, effects, and relationships. Neither sources nor own knowledge alone is enough.
questions.studyTip: Source says X. Own knowledge adds context: this happened because...

questions.text: 'Analyse' and 'explain' can be approached the same way.
questions.explanation: 'Analyse' specifically requires identifying components and the significance of relationships between them—factors that led to events and their consequences. It's more structural than 'explain'.
questions.studyTip: Analyse = break into parts + show how parts connect.

questions.text: 'Analyse' requires identifying components and explaining significant relationships between them.
questions.explanation: Analysis means breaking down a topic into factors and showing how they connect. What led to what? How did one thing cause another? Show the relationships.
questions.studyTip: Factor A led to B, which caused C. That's analysis.

questions.text: 'Evaluate' questions are best answered by describing everything you know about the topic.
questions.explanation: 'Evaluate' requires a clear judgement, not comprehensive description. The best responses address specific question demands rather than describing as much history as possible.
questions.studyTip: Evaluate = judge and justify. Not 'tell me everything'.

questions.text: 'Evaluate' questions require forming a judgement and supporting it with evidence.
questions.explanation: Take a position: To what extent? How significant? Make your judgement clear and support it with well-chosen evidence throughout your response.
questions.studyTip: State your judgement early. Defend it with evidence. Conclude clearly.

questions.text: Strong own knowledge can compensate for not using the source material.
questions.explanation: For 'explain' and 'analyse' questions, you must use both sources AND own knowledge. Responses that fail to explicitly reference source material don't score well, regardless of own knowledge quality.
questions.studyTip: Sources + own knowledge = required combination. Not either/or.

questions.text: High-scoring responses weave between source material and own knowledge throughout.
questions.explanation: The best responses integrate both elements seamlessly. Quote the source, add your contextual knowledge, connect to the question. This demonstrates both skills.
questions.studyTip: Source → own knowledge → question. Weave all three together.

concepts.title: Stay within the study design time period

questions.text: Background information from before the study design period shows thorough research.
questions.explanation: Information from outside the study design time period is not acceptable own knowledge. Don't discuss British colonisation of America or the Qing dynasty as 'own knowledge'—it's out of scope.
questions.studyTip: Know your revolution's dates. Nothing before, nothing after.

questions.text: Own knowledge must come from within the time period specified in the study design.
questions.explanation: The study design clearly indicates relevant time periods. References to Alexander II's 1861 emancipation, for example, are outside the Russian Revolution scope. Stay in period.
questions.studyTip: Check: Is this event within my revolution's dates? If not, don't use it.

questions.text: Detailed narration of events demonstrates strong historical knowledge.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses narrate events without connecting them to the question's specific demands. Every piece of evidence must link back to what's being asked.
questions.studyTip: Narrating events ≠ answering the question. Always connect to the prompt.

questions.text: Every piece of own knowledge must explicitly connect to the specific demands of the question.
questions.explanation: Don't just tell the story—show how it answers the question. Use connective phrases: 'which shows', 'this indicates', 'this suggests', 'this demonstrates'.
questions.studyTip: After each fact, ask: How does this answer the question?

questions.text: Discussing related individuals or events beyond the question focus shows breadth of knowledge.
questions.explanation: Questions often focus on specific individuals, groups, or events. Going beyond to discuss other figures or groups as your focal point costs marks. Stay on the assigned topic.
questions.studyTip: Question about Paine? Write about Paine. Not Washington.

questions.text: Responses must remain focused on the specific individual, group, or event named in the question.
questions.explanation: If the question asks about Marie Antoinette, discuss Marie Antoinette. Tangents to other figures dilute your response and suggest lack of focus.
questions.studyTip: Name in question = focus of answer. Don't drift.

concepts.title: Use historians to supplement, not replace, your argument

questions.text: Building your response around historians' quotes shows sophisticated understanding.
questions.explanation: Responses that use historians as the basis for arguments, rather than developing their own voice, score in mid to lower ranges. Your contention should drive the response, with historians supporting.
questions.studyTip: Your voice first. Historians support. Not the other way around.

questions.text: The highest-scoring responses use the student's 'own voice' as the vehicle for arguments, with historians supplementing.
questions.explanation: Develop your own contention first. Then use historical interpretations to enrich and support your argument. The historian adds depth; they don't replace your thinking.
questions.studyTip: Make your argument. Then: 'This is supported by [historian]...'

questions.text: Name-dropping a historian after a short quote demonstrates use of interpretation.
questions.explanation: Simply attributing a quote to a historian without explanation doesn't add value. Historical interpretations must be explained and contextualised within your argument.
questions.studyTip: Don't name-drop. Explain what the historian argues and why it matters.

questions.text: Historical interpretations must be fully explained and linked to your argument's context.
questions.explanation: Show you understand what the historian concluded and how it supports your point. A historian's view is only valuable when integrated into your reasoning.
questions.studyTip: [Historian] argues [X] because [Y]. This supports my point that...

questions.text: Any historian quote, even a short phrase, adds sophistication to your response.
questions.explanation: Generic quotes like 'tensions flared' or single-word quotes like 'paralysed' indicate lack of critical understanding. Use substantial, meaningful quotes that express actual historical opinions.
questions.studyTip: One word in quotes isn't a historical interpretation. It's decoration.

questions.text: Meaningful historical interpretations express specific conclusions from historians' research.
questions.explanation: A historical interpretation is a conclusion a historian reached after extensive research. It should express a view about causes, consequences, or significance—not just a descriptive phrase.
questions.studyTip: Good quote: specific argument. Bad quote: generic phrase.

questions.text: If you can't remember which revolution a historian wrote about, it's fine to use their quote anyway.
questions.explanation: Citing historians associated with different revolutions, or applying interpretations outside their context, shows misunderstanding and detracts from your response.
questions.studyTip: Wrong historian = wrong revolution = lost credibility.

questions.text: Historians must be correctly matched to their revolution and their quotes used in appropriate context.
questions.explanation: Know which historians write on which revolutions. Figes writes on Russia, not France. Misattribution is a significant error that undermines your credibility.
questions.studyTip: Make a list: Historian → Revolution → Key argument. Memorise it.

concepts.title: Historical interpretations are optional but valuable

questions.text: You must include historical interpretations to achieve high marks.
questions.explanation: Historical interpretations are not mandatory for high marks. Some students achieve excellent results relying exclusively on their own knowledge and primary sources.
questions.studyTip: No historians? You can still score highly with strong own knowledge.

questions.text: Historical interpretations add depth when properly integrated, but aren't required for full marks.
questions.explanation: Interpretations can enrich your response when well-used, but poorly integrated quotes can hurt more than help. If unsure, strong own knowledge is safer.
questions.studyTip: Well-used historian = depth. Poorly used = weakness. Choose wisely.

concepts.title: Form a clear judgement for 'evaluate' questions

questions.text: Covering all relevant events thoroughly is more important than forming a judgement.
questions.explanation: Evaluate questions require a clear judgement—not comprehensive coverage. Take a position on the extent, significance, or validity of the premise and defend it.
questions.studyTip: Evaluate = take a side and prove it. Not 'here's everything I know'.

questions.text: The best 'evaluate' responses state a clear judgement early and support it throughout.
questions.explanation: Don't wait until the conclusion to reveal your view. State your judgement in your opening, develop it through the body, and reinforce it at the end.
questions.studyTip: Opening: 'To a great/limited extent...' Then prove it.

questions.text: Focusing deeply on one key event is better than covering the whole period.
questions.explanation: Higher-scoring responses span the entire relevant time period. Don't skip to one noteworthy event while ignoring what came before—show understanding of the full scope.
questions.studyTip: Cover the whole period. Don't just discuss the famous event.

questions.text: Effective extended responses cover the entire time period relevant to the topic.
questions.explanation: More sophisticated responses identify continuities and changes across the period, not just between pre- and post-revolutionary times. Show the full picture.
questions.studyTip: Start to finish of the period. Show change over time.

concepts.title: Evaluate questions focus on Area of Study 2

questions.text: Extended responses can focus primarily on Area of Study 1 content.
questions.explanation: Evaluate questions in Section A are based on Area of Study 2. Responses with expansive discussion of AoS 1 without addressing change that occurred don't fully answer the question.
questions.studyTip: Section A evaluate = Area of Study 2. Know the difference.

questions.text: Section A 'evaluate' questions require discussion of change and consequences (Area of Study 2).
questions.explanation: These questions assess your understanding of the post-revolutionary period and changes that occurred. Pre-revolutionary content alone is insufficient.
questions.studyTip: AoS 1 = causes. AoS 2 = consequences. Evaluate questions need AoS 2.

concepts.title: Use sources in evaluate questions strategically

questions.text: Source material is required for full marks in 'evaluate' questions.
questions.explanation: Some evaluate questions don't require source material—own evidence and judgement are sufficient. Check whether sources are specified. If not, you won't be penalised for omitting them.
questions.studyTip: Check: Does this evaluate question require sources? Not all do.

questions.text: When 'evaluate' questions require sources, responses without source material cannot receive high scores.
questions.explanation: If the question specifies using sources, you must incorporate them. Responses that fail to include required sources are capped in marks.
questions.studyTip: Sources required? Use them. Sources optional? Your choice.

questions.text: A strong essay demonstrates extensive knowledge of the revolutionary period.
questions.explanation: Essays require 'construction of coherent and relevant historical argument'—not just knowledge display. Lengthy description or narration doesn't score as well as clear, relevant argument.
questions.studyTip: Argument > information dump. Make a case, don't just tell the story.

questions.text: High-scoring essays have a clear contention that directly addresses the specific question.
questions.explanation: Your essay needs a central argument that responds to exactly what's asked. This contention should be stated in your introduction and developed throughout every paragraph.
questions.studyTip: Intro: State your argument. Body: Prove it. Conclusion: Confirm it.

questions.text: A well-prepared essay on your revolution can be adapted to fit any question.
questions.explanation: Pre-prepared essays that abandon the question prompt and discuss other factors don't score well. You must explicitly address what the question asks, not what you prepared.
questions.studyTip: Pre-prepared ≠ pre-fitted. Adapt to THIS question.

questions.text: Responses that ignore the specific topic in the question and provide pre-prepared content score poorly.
questions.explanation: If the question asks about popular movements, discuss popular movements. Essays on other causes of revolution without connecting to the prompt don't address the question.
questions.studyTip: Question says X. Your essay must discuss X. Not just your favourite topic.

questions.text: Narrating the revolutionary period chronologically demonstrates strong knowledge.
questions.explanation: Many responses fall into narrative—recounting events without constructing argument. Essays must analyse and argue, not just tell what happened.
questions.studyTip: Narration tells. Argument analyses. Essays need argument.

questions.text: Essays must construct analytical arguments, not narrate events chronologically.
questions.explanation: Each paragraph should advance your argument, not just cover the next period. Use topic sentences that make analytical claims, then support with evidence.
questions.studyTip: Each paragraph: claim → evidence → link to argument. Not 'then this happened'.

concepts.title: Don't use Section A sources in essays

questions.text: Using sources from Section A in your essay shows efficient use of exam materials.
questions.explanation: Direct reference to Section A source material should be avoided in essays. Using provided sources suggests a deficiency in your own knowledge.
questions.studyTip: Essay = own knowledge only. Section A sources stay in Section A.

questions.text: Essays require own evidence, and using Section A sources indicates insufficient preparation.
questions.explanation: The essay tests your independent knowledge. Relying on exam-provided sources shows you haven't prepared your own evidence. Use your studied material.
questions.studyTip: Prepare your own quotes, dates, statistics. Don't borrow from Section A.

questions.text: Restating the question at the start and end of paragraphs is sufficient signposting.
questions.explanation: Simply bookending paragraphs with question restatements isn't effective signposting. Higher-scoring essays maintain continuous alignment with the prompt throughout.
questions.studyTip: Signpost through the paragraph, not just at the edges.

questions.text: High-scoring essays seamlessly integrate relevance to the question throughout every paragraph.
questions.explanation: Don't just start and end with the question—connect to it throughout. Topic sentences should make claims relevant to the question; evidence should support those claims.
questions.studyTip: Every few sentences: How does this answer the question? Make it explicit.

concepts.title: Address all parts of multi-part questions

questions.text: Focusing on the most important part of a multi-part question is an effective strategy.
questions.explanation: If a question has multiple parts, all parts must be explicitly addressed. Ignoring any element of the question means not fully answering it.
questions.studyTip: Count the parts. Address all of them. Missing one = incomplete answer.

questions.text: Essay questions with multiple parts require explicit discussion of each component.
questions.explanation: Break down the question: What are all the things it asks? Plan to address each element. Structure your essay to cover every component.
questions.studyTip: Underline each part of the question. Tick them off as you address them.

questions.text: Key terms in the question have obvious meanings that don't need definition.
questions.explanation: Defining key terms provides clarity and focus. What counts as a 'popular movement'? What does 'devastated' mean? Your definitions shape your argument.
questions.studyTip: Define key terms = show you understand what's actually being asked.

questions.text: Defining key terms in your introduction provides clarity and focus for your argument.
questions.explanation: Definitions establish the scope of your essay. If the question asks about 'popular movements', explain what you're including in that category.
questions.studyTip: Intro: 'By [term], I mean...' Then argue within that definition.

questions.text: You must agree with the proposition stated in the essay question.
questions.explanation: Responses can challenge the premise if they provide clear justification. If you think the stated factor wasn't the main cause of revolution, argue that—with evidence.
questions.studyTip: Disagree? That's fine. But justify your position with evidence.

questions.text: Challenging the essay premise is acceptable if you provide clear justification and evidence.
questions.explanation: Some students successfully challenged premises (e.g., that liberal ideas led to Russia's revolution). The key is strong argumentation and evidence for your alternative view.
questions.studyTip: Agree, disagree, or partially agree. Any position works if well-argued.

questions.text: The Boston Tea Party is an example of a popular movement.
questions.explanation: Students often conflate events (Boston Tea Party, Boston Massacre) with movements (Sons of Liberty). Events are incidents; movements are organised groups pursuing change.
questions.studyTip: Event = what happened. Movement = organised group. Different things.

questions.text: Popular movements are organised groups, not individual events or incidents.
questions.explanation: The Sons of Liberty is a movement. The Boston Tea Party is an event carried out by that movement. Know the difference and discuss appropriately.
questions.studyTip: Movement = people organised for a cause over time. Not a single event.

questions.text: If you remember a good quote but forget the historian, attribute it to a historian you do remember.
questions.explanation: Misattributing quotes to historians detracts from your response. If you can't remember who said something, paraphrase instead of inventing an attribution.
questions.studyTip: Wrong attribution = worse than no attribution. When unsure, paraphrase.

questions.text: Incorrectly attributing quotes to historians undermines your credibility and response quality.
questions.explanation: Assessors notice when quotes are misattributed. This shows confusion about your sources. Only attribute quotes you're confident about.
questions.studyTip: Certain? Quote and attribute. Uncertain? Paraphrase without attribution.

questions.text: Any content from your revolution study can be used for any question.
questions.explanation: Some students misread questions and write exclusively on the wrong time period (e.g., post-revolutionary when asked about causes). Read carefully which period is required.
questions.studyTip: What time period does THIS question ask about? Answer that period.

questions.text: You must identify whether the question asks about pre-revolutionary, revolutionary, or post-revolutionary periods.
questions.explanation: A question about outbreak of revolution needs pre-revolutionary content. A question about consolidation needs post-revolutionary content. Match your answer to the period asked.
questions.studyTip: 'Outbreak' = before. 'Consolidation' = after. Read the question carefully.

questions.text: Including as many events, dates, and policies as possible demonstrates strong knowledge.
questions.explanation: Higher-scoring responses are judicious in selecting evidence—they don't try to cover everything. Quality and relevance beat quantity. Choose evidence that directly supports your argument.
questions.studyTip: Select, don't dump. Choose evidence that proves your point.

questions.text: Effective responses use carefully selected, highly relevant evidence rather than trying to include everything.
questions.explanation: Selectivity shows judgement. Pick the most powerful examples that support your specific argument. Comprehensive coverage often means superficial treatment.
questions.studyTip: Ask: Does this evidence help my argument? If not, leave it out.

questions.text: Historical interpretations alone are sufficient evidence for essays.
questions.explanation: Higher-scoring responses combine various forms of evidence: primary sources, dates, statistics, policies, laws, events, AND historical interpretations. Use a mix.
questions.studyTip: Mix it up: quotes, dates, statistics, policies, historian views.

questions.text: The best responses weave together primary sources, specific facts, and historical interpretations.
questions.explanation: Variety of evidence shows breadth of knowledge and sophisticated argumentation. Don't rely on just one type—combine different forms throughout your response.
questions.studyTip: Each paragraph: fact + quote + date or statistic. Variety shows depth.

questions.text: Modern historical interpretations are more valuable than contemporary perspectives.
questions.explanation: Perspectives of people during the revolution add depth to arguments. Quotes from revolutionary figures, contemporary observers, or primary documents show you understand the period's voices.
questions.studyTip: What did people then think? Include their voices, not just historians.

questions.text: Including perspectives from people who lived through the revolution adds depth to your argument.
questions.explanation: Contemporary voices—revolutionaries, leaders, ordinary people—bring the period alive. Use primary source quotes alongside historical interpretations.
questions.studyTip: Balance: What historians say + what people then said.

questions.text: Approximate dates and rough details are acceptable if your argument is strong.
questions.explanation: Accurate details—dates, names, policies—strengthen your credibility. Errors in basic facts undermine otherwise good arguments. Get the details right.
questions.studyTip: Wrong date = undermined credibility. Learn key dates accurately.

questions.text: Accurate dates, correctly spelled names, and precise policy references strengthen your response.
questions.explanation: Precision matters. Higher-scoring responses demonstrate accuracy in their evidence. Double-check your key dates, names, and facts during revision.
questions.studyTip: Make flashcards: event → date → significance. Get them right.

questions.text: Clear analytical arguments can stand on their own without specific evidence.
questions.explanation: Every claim needs supporting evidence. Arguments without evidence are assertions. High-scoring responses justify all claims with relevant, specific own knowledge.
questions.studyTip: Claim without evidence = assertion. Always back up what you say.

questions.text: Every argument you make must be supported with specific, relevant evidence.
questions.explanation: Don't make claims you can't support. If you argue something was significant, show why with evidence. If you say something caused something else, prove it.
questions.studyTip: For every claim: What's my evidence? If none, reconsider the claim.
